section.heading: Determination of number of job vacancies; reporting.

content.p: To the extent that money is available, the board of trustees of a school district shall determine the number of job vacancies based on the number of licensed teachers needed to achieve the recommended ratios of pupils per licensed teacher prescribed by the State Board pursuant toNRS 388.890. A position held by a full-time substitute teacher shall be considered vacant for the purposes of this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The board of trustees of each school district shall post on the Internet website maintained by the school district the number of positions within the school district that are held by full-time substitute teachers and teachers licensed or working towards obtaining a license through an alternative route to licensure. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On or before February 1 of each even-numbered year, the board of trustees of each school district shall report to the Joint Interim Standing Committee on Education the: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Number of teachers employed by the school district who are working towards obtaining a license by participating in a program for an alternative route to licensure; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of each program for an alternative route to licensure in which teachers employed by the school district are participating; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The number of teachers employed by the school district who are participating in each program for an alternative route to licensure identified pursuant to paragraph
; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The rate of completion of teachers employed by the school district in each program for an alternative route to licensure identified pursuant to paragraph
; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The rate of retention by the school district of teachers who participate in each program for an alternative route to licensure.

section.heading: Involuntary transfer or reassignment of unlicensed employees.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, any involuntary transfer or reassignment of an unlicensed employee must be based on assignment and seniority and may not be made as a form of discipline. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An unlicensed employee may be reassigned for less than 30 days in response to temporary requirements for work. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Standards for determining.

content.p: The salaries of teachers and other employees must be determined by the character of the service required as described inNRS 391.161to391.169, inclusive. A school district shall not discriminate between male and female employees in the matter of salary.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Use of testing as factor in vertical promotion; appeals; prohibited acts; exception.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, notwithstanding the provisions of any collective bargaining agreement to the contrary, if the superintendent of schools or the board of trustees of a school district includes testing as a factor in a decision regarding the vertical promotion of an employee: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The testing must be conducted by a third party which is independent from the superintendent or the board of trustees, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A third party which conducts a test must send to each employee who takes the test a confidential electronic mail message which contains the employeeï¿½s test score. The third party must send an employeeï¿½s test score to the employee and the superintendent or the board of trustees at the same time. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The superintendent or the board of trustees, as applicable, shall not produce a list of the employees who took the test, ranked in order of their test scores, until after the third party which conducted the test has sent each employee his or her test score pursuant to paragraph
. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An employee who is aggrieved by his or her test score may appeal the testing process. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
During the appeal process authorized by paragraph
of subsection 1: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The employee who appeals the testing process is entitled to see: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The questions which the employee answered incorrectly. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The superintendent or the board of trustees, as applicable, shall ensure that the employee was ranked properly based on the employeeï¿½s test score. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who tampers with the score of a test taken by an employee is guilty of a category E felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to a district or school department that has less than 200 employees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½testï¿½ and ï¿½testingï¿½ includes, without limitation, a written test, oral board or any other form or format of test of knowledge, skills, achievement or aptitude.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Increased salary for certain teachers who are certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards.

content.p: On or before January 31 of the school year, the teacher has submitted evidence satisfactory to the school district of his or her current certification; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The teacher is assigned by the school district to provide classroom instruction during that school year. ï¿½No increase in salary may be given pursuant to this section during a particular school year to a teacher who submits evidence of certification after January 31 of that school year. For the first school year that a teacher submits evidence of his or her current certification, the board of trustees of the school district to whom the evidence was submitted shall pay the increase in salary required by this section retroactively to the beginning of that school year. Once a teacher has submitted evidence of such certification to the school district, the school district shall retain the evidence in its records, as applicable, for future school years. An increase in salary given in accordance with this section is in addition to any other increase to which the teacher may otherwise be entitled.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Increased salary for certain speech-language pathologists.

content.p: On or before September 15 of the school year, the employee has submitted evidence satisfactory to the school district of the employeeï¿½s: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An increase in salary given in accordance with this section is in addition to any other increase to which the employee may otherwise be entitled.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Increased salary for certain professional school library media specialists with additional certification.

content.p: On or before September 15 of the school year, the employee has submitted evidence satisfactory to the school district of the employeeï¿½s current certification as a professional school library media specialist issued by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Once an employee has submitted evidence of such certification to the school district, the school district shall retain the evidence in its records, as applicable, for future school years. An increase in salary given in accordance with this section is in addition to any other increase to which the employee may otherwise be entitled.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Credit for previous teaching service.

content.p: In determining the salary of a licensed teacher who is employed by a school district after the teacher has been employed by another school district in this State, the present employer shall, except as otherwise provided in subsection 3: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Give the teacher the same credit for previous teaching service as the teacher was receiving from the teacherï¿½s former employer at the end of his or her former employment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Give the teacher credit for the teacherï¿½s final year of service with his or her former employer, if credit for that service is not included in credit given pursuant to paragraph
; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Place the teacher on the schedule of salaries of the school district in a classification that is commensurate with the level of education acquired by the teacher, as set forth in the applicable negotiated agreement with the present employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A school district may give the credit required by subsection 1 for previous teaching service earned in another state if the Commission has approved the standards for licensing teachers of that state. The Commission shall adopt regulations that establish the criteria by which the Commission will consider the standards for licensing teachers of other states for the purposes of this subsection. The criteria may include, without limitation, whether the Commission has authorized reciprocal licensure of educational personnel from the state under consideration. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a school district to allow a teacher more credit for previous teaching service than the maximum credit for teaching experience provided for in the schedule of salaries established by it for its licensed personnel. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Permit a school district to deny a teacher credit for his or her previous teaching service on the ground that the service differs in kind from the teaching experience for which credit is otherwise given by the school district. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½previous teaching serviceï¿½ means the total of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any period of teaching service for which a teacher received credit from the teacherï¿½s former employer at the beginning of his or her former employment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The teacherï¿½s period of teaching service in his or her former employment.

section.heading: Determination of salaries: Credit for previous administrative service.

content.p: In determining the salary of a licensed administrator, other than the superintendent of schools, who is employed by a school district after the administrator has been employed by another school district in this State, the present employer shall, except as otherwise provided in subsection 2: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Give the administrator the same credit for previous administrative service as the administrator was receiving from the administratorï¿½s former employer, at the end of his or her former employment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Give the administrator credit for the administratorï¿½s final year of service with his or her former employer, if credit for that service is not otherwise included in the credit given pursuant to paragraph
; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Place the administrator on the schedule of salaries of the school district in a classification that is comparable to the classification the administrator had attained on the schedule of salaries of the administratorï¿½s former employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Require a school district to allow an administrator more credit for previous administrative service than the maximum credit for administrative experience provided for in the schedule of salaries established by it for its licensed personnel. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Permit a school district to deny an administrator credit for his or her previous administrative service on the ground that the service differs in kind from the administrative experience for which credit is otherwise given by the school district. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½previous administrative serviceï¿½ means the total of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any period of administrative service for which an administrator received credit from the administratorï¿½s former employer at the beginning of his or her former employment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The administratorï¿½s period of administrative service in his or her former employment.

section.heading: Conditions for receipt of public money as compensation by certain teachers and other employees; exception for charter schools.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a teacher or other employee for whom a license is required is not entitled to receive any portion of public money for schools as compensation for services rendered unless he or she: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is legally employed by the board of trustees of the school district or the governing body of the charter school in which he or she is teaching or performing other educational functions. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has a license authorizing him or her to teach or perform other educational functions at the level and, except as otherwise provided inNRS 391.125, in the field for which he or she is employed, issued in accordance with law and in full force at the time the services are rendered. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of subsection 1 do not prohibit the payment of public money to teachers or other employees who are employed by a charter school who are not required to hold a license or endorsement to teach pursuant to the provisions ofNRS 388A.518.

section.heading: Reservation of money for negotiated salary increase; money does not revert and must not be subtracted from operating expenses.

content.p: If a school district negotiates with an employee organization pursuant toNRS 288.150to increase the salary of employees for a fiscal year, the board of trustees of the school district shall reserve for that fiscal year an amount of money sufficient, when combined with any appropriation for that purpose and any money remaining in the account established pursuant to subsection 2, to carry out each such increase in the salary of an employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, the money reserved by a board of trustees pursuant to subsection 1 and any money provided by appropriation to increase the salary of an employee of the school district who is subject to a negotiated increase in salary described in subsection 1 must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Accounted for separately by the school district. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Used only to pay an increase in salaries in accordance with subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any money reserved pursuant to subsection 1 for a fiscal year that remains in the account established pursuant to subsection 2 at the end of that fiscal year does not revert to the general fund of the school district, but must be carried forward to the next fiscal year and used only for the purpose of paying an increase in salaries negotiated between a school district and an employee organization pursuant toNRS 288.150in subsequent fiscal years. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any money reserved pursuant to subsection 1 must not be subtracted from the operating expenses of the school district for purposes of determining the budget of the school district for any other fiscal year.

section.heading: Payment of salaries of certain teachers and other employees from apportionment of public money; deductions from salary.

content.p: Boards of trustees of school districts in this state may pay toward the salaries of teachers and other employees the public money apportioned to school districts for that purpose, by giving them orders therefor on the county auditor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Boards of trustees may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Reduce or withhold from the salary of any teacher or other employee, upon the written request of the teacher or employee, an amount specified in the request to be held by the trustees pursuant to a deferred compensation agreement between the trustees and the teacher or other employee.

section.heading: Absences of employees: Compensation; deductions; accumulation and transfer of sick leave; intermission and extension of days of school.

content.p: As used in this section, ï¿½employeeï¿½ means any employee of a school district or charter school in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A school month in any public school in this State consists of 4 weeks of 5 days each. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The per diem deduction from the salary of an employee because of absence from service for reasons other than those specified in this section is that proportion of the yearly salary which is determined by the ratio between the duration of the absence and the total number of contracted workdays in the year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Boards of trustees shall either prescribe by regulation or negotiate pursuant tochapter 288of NRS, with respect to sick leave, accumulation of sick leave, payment for unused sick leave, sabbatical leave, personal leave, professional leave, military leave and such other leave as they determine to be necessary or desirable for employees. Subject to the provisions of subsection 8: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

of subsection 7, an employee may be required to render his or her services to the school district or charter school during that extended period. If the salary of the employee was continued during the period of intermission as provided in subsection 7, the employee is not entitled to additional compensation for services rendered during the extended period. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If any subject referred to in this section is included in an agreement or contract negotiated by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Legislative declaration.

content.p: Persons who enter professions that necessitate interaction with the pupils of this State have an obligation to act professionally and ethically when dealing with a pupil; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Establishment of Code; training on Code to teachers, administrators and others; posting of Code on Internet website.

content.p: The Commission shall prescribe by regulation a written policy that establishes the Nevada Model Code of Educator Ethics for teachers, administrators and other persons employed by a school district or a charter school relating to interpersonal interactions and communications with pupils. The Nevada Model Code of Educator Ethics must, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Be developed in consultation with the boards of trustees of school districts, the governing bodies of charter schools and, as practicable, teachers, administrators and other persons employed by school districts and charter schools. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Clearly state the guidelines for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Responsibility to pupils; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Responsibility to the school community; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Exercise of trusteesï¿½ authority in school by certain personnel.
